title: MathQuest: CBSE Class 7 Maths Mastery + Olympiad + Engineering Foundation
audience_notes: Primary track aligns to CBSE/NCERT Class 7 Mathematics. Learning design prioritizes long‑term retention (retrieval + spacing) and confidence-safe error handling.
Olympiad track adds non‑routine reasoning (number theory, counting, geometry) while keeping explanations concrete and age-appropriate.
Engineering foundation track supports the long runway to AP EAPCET by strengthening algebraic fluency, coordinate thinking, and interpretation skills early (without speed pressure in Grade 7).
design_goals: Long-term retention (spaced retrieval) over short-term performance
Low-glitz, high-signal UI: every interaction must reveal thinking or build a mental model

levels.definition: Can solve with scaffolding/hints; recognizes the idea.
Can solve standard items independently with high accuracy.
Can solve efficiently and accurately; low working-memory load.
Can apply in new contexts/representations and explain why.

rule_of_thumb: Any atom not touched for 7+ days re-enters warmups.
A wrong answer schedules an earlier review (next day).
Mastery checks are cumulative: include prerequisites 30–40% of the time.

when_correct: Highlight the key idea or strategy used
when_incorrect: Do not shame; label the misconception
Provide one actionable hint (not the full solution) on attempt 1
Provide a worked example or step scaffold on attempt 2
anti_glitz_rules: Motion must encode math (transformations, balance, movement along number line) or be removed.

scoring_models.rubric_lite: Short explanation checked against key points (template-controlled)

micro_lesson_flow.purpose: Activate curiosity with a concrete context or visual.
rules: No scoring here; this is exploration.

micro_lesson_flow.purpose: Show the core idea with one clean worked example.
Learner practices with support; capture process.
Make them pull it out of memory; build fluency.
Find and fix the most common wrong idea.
Same idea in a new outfit; lock in understanding.
rules: Different representation or context than practice.

weekly_mastery_check.coverage: Mix of current + prerequisites; mostly retrieval

weekly_routine.celebration_rule: Celebrate streaks and persistence, not speed alone.

template_onboarding.rule: Introduce a new template with 2–3 unscored practice items + one scored easy item. Do not mix multiple new templates in the same session.

onboarding_steps.name: Watch it once
onboarding_steps.description: Show a single example interaction with the UI elements highlighted.

onboarding_steps.name: Try with hints
onboarding_steps.description: Learner completes 2 items with strong scaffolding and unlimited undo.

onboarding_steps.name: Try without hints
onboarding_steps.description: One easy item scored; unlocks using that template in mastery sessions.

principles: Generate from math intent (atom) first, not from template first.
Every generated item must have: a single core target (atom) + optional prerequisite check.
Prefer retrieval templates (NUMERIC_INPUT / EXPRESSION_INPUT) for mastery decisions.
MCQ is allowed but must be backed by misconception-based distractors.

difficulty_tiers.name: Stretch
difficulty_tiers.description: Trick-free but demanding; multi-step or unfamiliar representation.

constraints: Avoid accidental simplification traps unless intended (e.g., 0 denominators, negative under radicals if not taught).
Ensure unique correct answer for MCQ; if ambiguous, switch template to NUMERIC_INPUT.
Maintain value ranges appropriate for Grade 7 mental load.

distractor_generation_for_mcq.rule: Every distractor must map to a named misconception or common procedural slip.
distractor_types: Denominator mistake (add denominators / forget common denom)
Units slip (cm vs cm² vs cm³)
Using wrong base for percent change

must_include: final answer with units if any

solution_requirements.feedback_map: per_common_wrong_answer provide targeted hint and misconception label

modules.title: Problem-Solving Foundations (all chapters)
big_ideas: Good solvers represent the problem before calculating.
Checking is part of solving: estimate, use units, and reverse operations.
Explaining your reasoning makes your thinking stronger and reveals gaps.

atoms.title: Plan–Solve–Check (a repeatable routine)
atoms.core_idea: A simple routine reduces careless errors and increases understanding.
learning_objectives: Identify what is asked, what is given, and what is unknown.
Choose a representation (number line, table, diagram, equation).
Check by estimation, units, or reverse operation.
common_misconceptions: Jumping straight to calculations without a plan.
Thinking checking is only needed when unsure.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Annotate a worked example: plan → solve → check.
Find the step where reasoning broke.

atoms.title: Estimation & Reasonableness Checks
atoms.core_idea: Estimation is a safety net: your answer should make sense in size and units. Start with whole-number rounding; extend to decimals later.
learning_objectives: Round numbers to estimate results quickly.
Detect unreasonable answers (wrong magnitude).
Use inverse operations to verify.
common_misconceptions: Believing estimation is 'guessing' and not useful.
Only checking the final step, not the model.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Estimate 48×19 using rounding then compute exact.
Which answer is reasonable and why?

atoms.title: Explain Your Reasoning (short proofs)
atoms.core_idea: A short explanation uses a claim, evidence (math fact), and a conclusion.
learning_objectives: Write a 1–2 sentence justification using a known fact.
Use sentence frames ('Because..., therefore...').
Identify missing steps in an explanation.
common_misconceptions: Thinking explanation is just restating the answer.
Writing too much without referencing a math fact.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Pick the reason then rewrite it in your own words.

modules.title: Chapter 1: Integers
big_ideas: Integers extend whole numbers to include negatives and zero.
The number line is a map of magnitude; distance and direction matter.
Operations on integers can be understood as movement patterns, not memorized rules.

atoms.title: Integers on the Number Line (compare & order)
atoms.core_idea: Integers represent positions on a number line; to compare, look at who is to the right.
learning_objectives: Place positive, negative, and zero on a number line.
Compare and order integers using >, <.
Explain why -3 is greater than -7 using the number line.
common_misconceptions: Thinking that -7 is greater than -3 because 7 > 3.
Treating negatives as 'not real' or ignoring the sign.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Place and sort numbers; talk benchmarks (-10, -5, 0, 5, 10).
Order 5 integers; then choose the correct explanation.
Elevators: basement floors vs above ground.

atoms.title: Add & Subtract Integers (as movement)
atoms.core_idea: Adding moves right/left on the number line; subtraction is adding the opposite.
learning_objectives: Add integers using a number line model.
Subtract integers by rewriting as addition of the opposite.
Explain why subtracting a negative increases the value.
common_misconceptions: Mixing up signs when subtracting negatives.
Thinking subtraction always makes numbers smaller.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Move and record; then rewrite subtraction.

atoms.title: Multiply & Divide Integers (pattern + meaning)
atoms.core_idea: Signs in multiplication/division follow a consistent pattern that preserves arithmetic structure.
learning_objectives: Multiply and divide integers correctly.
Justify sign rules using patterns (e.g., decreasing by 3).
Identify and correct common sign mistakes.
common_misconceptions: Believing 'two negatives make a negative'.
Applying addition sign rules to multiplication.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Sort sign outcomes; fill missing pattern entries.

atoms.title: Order of Operations with Integers
atoms.core_idea: A standard order (brackets, exponents, multiplication/division, addition/subtraction) prevents ambiguity.
learning_objectives: Evaluate expressions with integers using correct order of operations.
Use parentheses to change the value intentionally.
Spot and correct order-of-operations mistakes.
common_misconceptions: Working strictly left-to-right always.
Ignoring parentheses or treating them as decoration.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Show two expressions that look similar but differ by parentheses.
Create parentheses to hit a target result.

atoms.title: Absolute Value as Distance
atoms.core_idea: Absolute value measures distance from zero, not 'making a number positive' as a trick.
learning_objectives: Interpret |a| as distance from 0.
Solve simple distance questions (e.g., distance between -3 and 5).
Avoid common absolute value misconceptions.
common_misconceptions: Thinking |−5| = −5.
Thinking absolute value changes the direction of movement.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Distance between two points on number line.
Bank account: how far in debt, how far from goal.

atoms.title: Integer Word Problems (Model + Check)
atoms.core_idea: A good model (number line or context table) plus a reasonableness check prevents sign errors.
learning_objectives: Translate a word situation into integer operations.
Choose a representation (number line/table) and solve.
Check reasonableness using estimation or a reverse operation.
common_misconceptions: Picking the wrong operation because of keywords ('more', 'less').
Not checking if the sign makes sense in context.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Show Plan-Solve-Check with a temperature story.

modules.title: Chapter 2: Fractions and Decimals
big_ideas: Fractions describe parts of a whole and ratios; equivalent fractions are the same value in different forms.
Magnitude matters: place fractions and decimals on a number line to reason, not guess.
Operations on fractions have meanings (scaling, sharing), not just rules.

atoms.title: Fractions: Meaning, Equivalence, Simplifying
atoms.core_idea: Equivalent fractions represent the same point on the number line; simplifying is dividing numerator and denominator by the same non-zero number.
learning_objectives: Explain a fraction as a number (not two separate numbers).
Generate equivalent fractions using multiplication/division by the same number.
Simplify fractions using common factors.
common_misconceptions: Adding same number to top and bottom keeps value.
Thinking larger denominator always means larger value.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Student adds 1 to numerator and denominator.
Recipe scaling: same taste, different batch size.

atoms.title: Compare & Order Fractions and Decimals
atoms.core_idea: To compare, use benchmarks (0, 1/2, 1) or common denominators or convert to decimals.
learning_objectives: Compare two fractions using benchmarks or common denominator.
Compare decimals using place value and number line.
Order a mix of fractions and decimals.
common_misconceptions: Comparing fractions by comparing denominators only.
Treating 0.35 as greater than 0.5 because 35 > 5.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Place then choose best comparison reason.
Order a set; choose which is bigger.

atoms.title: Add & Subtract Fractions (including mixed numbers)
atoms.core_idea: Fractions can only be added/subtracted when they refer to the same-sized parts (common denominator).
learning_objectives: Add/subtract fractions with like denominators.
Add/subtract fractions with unlike denominators using LCM.
Handle mixed numbers by converting or separating whole and fractional parts.
common_misconceptions: Adding numerators and denominators: a/b + c/d = (a+c)/(b+d).
Forgetting to convert mixed numbers or simplify.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Show why denominators must match; then compute with LCM.
Fill steps: find LCM → convert → add.
Mixed practice; include one mixed number.

atoms.title: Multiply Fractions (as scaling)
atoms.core_idea: Multiplying by a fraction scales a quantity; multiplying two fractions multiplies their parts.
learning_objectives: Multiply a fraction by a whole number and by another fraction.
Simplify before multiplying using common factors.
Interpret multiplication by a fraction as scaling (smaller/bigger).
common_misconceptions: Thinking multiplication always makes numbers bigger.
Multiplying denominators and numerators but forgetting to simplify or cancel.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Which statement about size is true?
Discount fraction of a price without percent.

atoms.title: Divide Fractions (meaning + invert-and-multiply)
atoms.core_idea: Dividing by a fraction asks 'how many of this fraction fit in that quantity?'
learning_objectives: Interpret division of fractions with a measurement model.
Compute fraction division using invert-and-multiply.
Check reasonableness (division by a fraction can increase the number).
common_misconceptions: Dividing numerators and denominators directly.
Thinking division always makes numbers smaller.

atoms.title: Decimals: Place Value, Rounding, and Operations
atoms.core_idea: Decimals are fractions with denominators of powers of 10; place value controls size.
learning_objectives: Convert between fractions (denominator 10/100/1000) and decimals.
Add/subtract decimals using alignment of place value.
Multiply/divide decimals by powers of 10; round and estimate to check.
common_misconceptions: Misaligning decimal points when adding/subtracting.
Moving decimal the wrong direction when multiplying/dividing by 10/100.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Mixed decimal operations; include estimation check.
Student lines up last digits instead of decimal points.

modules.title: Chapter 3: Data Handling
big_ideas: Data tells a story; representation choices affect what you see.
Measures of center (mean/median/mode) summarize differently.
Good reasoning includes questioning misleading graphs.

atoms.title: Collect, Organize, and Read Data (frequency tables)
atoms.core_idea: A frequency table organizes counts and supports graphing and analysis.
learning_objectives: Create a frequency table from raw data.
Read values from a table accurately.
Compute totals from frequencies.
common_misconceptions: Mixing up frequency with the data value.
Forgetting that frequencies must sum to total.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Convert raw list to frequency table.

atoms.title: Bar Graphs and Double Bar Graphs
atoms.core_idea: Bar graphs compare categories; double bars compare two groups on same categories.
learning_objectives: Read and interpret bar graphs and double bar graphs.
Create a simple bar graph from a table (conceptually).
Answer comparison questions using the graph.
common_misconceptions: Reading bar width instead of height.
Ignoring scale on the axis.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Match a table to its bar graph.
Tap the bar representing a given value.

atoms.title: Mean, Median, Mode (and when to use which)
atoms.core_idea: Different averages summarize different aspects; choose based on context and outliers.
learning_objectives: Compute mean, median, and mode for small data sets.
Explain when median might be better than mean.
Detect how an outlier changes mean vs median.
common_misconceptions: Thinking mean and median are always equal or similar.
Forgetting to order data for median.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Compute all three measures; discuss outlier effect.
Compute sets; identify which measure is best.
Income vs allowance story: pick mean/median.

atoms.title: Range and Simple Interpretation
atoms.core_idea: Range captures spread; interpretation answers what the data suggests, not what you wish it said.
learning_objectives: Compute range and compare spreads.
Make simple inferences from graphs/tables.
Distinguish observation from opinion.
common_misconceptions: Confusing range with mean.
Making claims not supported by data.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Compute range and interpret what it means.

atoms.title: Pie Charts (fractions of a whole)
atoms.core_idea: A pie chart represents parts of a whole; angle/sector size matches fraction/percent.
learning_objectives: Read fractions/percents from a pie chart.
Convert between fraction/percent for pie slices.
Create (conceptually) a pie chart from data.
common_misconceptions: Comparing slice perimeter instead of area/angle.
Forgetting total must be 100%.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Time spent in activities pie chart.

atoms.title: Misleading Graphs (critical thinking)
atoms.core_idea: Graphs can mislead through scale tricks or missing context; check axes and totals.
learning_objectives: Spot misleading scales and truncated axes.
Explain how the graph could mislead.
Suggest a corrected graph.
common_misconceptions: Assuming graphs are always honest.
Ignoring axis labels.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Debug a bar graph with truncated axis.
Rewrite a headline to match data honestly.

modules.title: Chapter 4: Simple Equations
big_ideas: An equation states two expressions are equal; solving means finding the value that makes it true.
Valid moves preserve equality by doing the same operation to both sides.
Checking is part of solving, not an optional extra.

atoms.title: Equation as Balance (what 'solve' means)
atoms.core_idea: An equation is a balance; every legal move keeps both sides equal.
learning_objectives: Explain what it means to solve an equation.
Identify whether a value satisfies an equation (check by substitution).
Distinguish expression vs equation.
common_misconceptions: Thinking '=' means 'the answer comes next' rather than 'both sides are same'.
Changing only one side.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Keep the scale balanced with simple moves.

atoms.title: Solve One-step Equations (x ± a = b)
atoms.core_idea: Undo addition/subtraction with the inverse operation on both sides.
learning_objectives: Solve x + a = b and x − a = b.
Explain the inverse operation used.
Check the solution.
common_misconceptions: Moving a term across the equals sign without understanding (sign flip errors).
Forgetting to check.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Remove the same amount from both sides.
Unknown amount in a story (tickets, points).

atoms.title: Solve One-step Equations (ax = b, x/a = b)
atoms.core_idea: Undo multiplication/division with inverse operation; keep equality by applying to both sides.
learning_objectives: Solve ax = b and x/a = b (including negative a).
Use division/multiplication correctly.
Check solutions.
common_misconceptions: Dividing only one side.
Confusing a×x with a+x.

atoms.title: Solve Two-step Equations (ax + b = c)
atoms.core_idea: Undo operations in reverse order: first remove b, then divide by a.
learning_objectives: Solve ax + b = c (including negatives).
Choose the correct undo order and justify it.
Check solutions.
common_misconceptions: Dividing before subtracting b (wrong order).
Distributing incorrectly when rewriting.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Arrange undo steps: subtract then divide.
Phone plan fixed fee + per-unit cost.

atoms.title: Inequalities (intro) and Number Line Graphing
atoms.core_idea: An inequality describes a range of values; the number line shows the set of solutions.
learning_objectives: Interpret symbols <, ≤, >, ≥.
Represent solutions on a number line.
Check whether a value satisfies an inequality.
common_misconceptions: Treating inequality like an equation with a single answer.
Reversing meaning of symbols.

modules.title: Chapter 5: Lines and Angles
big_ideas: Angle facts come from a few invariants (straight line 180°, around a point 360°).
Vertical angles are equal; linear pairs sum to 180°.
Diagram reasoning is about relationships, not guessing.

atoms.title: Angle Types and Measuring
atoms.core_idea: Angles measure turn; benchmark angles build estimation and sense-making.
learning_objectives: Identify acute, right, obtuse, straight, reflex angles.
Estimate and measure angles.
Use 90°, 180°, 360° as benchmarks.
common_misconceptions: Confusing angle size with side length in a diagram.
Thinking a larger drawn angle arm means larger angle.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Use benchmarks to estimate an angle.
Match angle pictures to type; tap examples.
Clock hands angle at a given time.

atoms.title: Angles on a Straight Line and Around a Point
atoms.core_idea: Angles on a straight line sum to 180°; around a point sum to 360°.
learning_objectives: Solve missing angle problems using 180° and 360° facts.
Explain reasoning using sum facts.
Check by substitution (do sums).
common_misconceptions: Adding angles incorrectly or mixing 180 and 360.
Assuming angles are equal without reason.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Find missing angle in a straight line.
Puzzle wheel with angles around point.

atoms.title: Vertical Angles and Linear Pairs
atoms.core_idea: Vertical angles are equal; a linear pair sums to 180°.
learning_objectives: Identify vertical angles and linear pairs in diagrams.
Compute unknown angles using equality/sum relations.
Explain which relationship you used.
common_misconceptions: Confusing adjacent angles with vertical angles.
Assuming any opposite-looking angles are equal.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Use vertical equality then linear pair sum.

atoms.title: Complementary and Supplementary Angles
atoms.core_idea: Complementary angles sum to 90°; supplementary sum to 180°.
learning_objectives: Determine complements and supplements of given angles.
Use these relationships in simple problems.
Avoid mixing up 90° and 180°.
common_misconceptions: Swapping complementary and supplementary.
Assuming complementary means equal.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Right angle corner split into two angles.

atoms.title: Angle Problem Solving (multi-step diagrams)
atoms.core_idea: Complex diagrams are solved by chaining small facts: equal angles, sums, and known benchmarks.
learning_objectives: Solve multi-step angle problems with 2–3 relations.
Write a short explanation of the chain of reasoning.
Check with total sums.
common_misconceptions: Randomly guessing equations without identifying relationships first.
Ignoring given information in diagram.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Diagram-based multi-step items with structured steps.
Create a diagram with one vertical and one linear pair relation.

modules.title: Chapter 6: The Triangle and its Properties
big_ideas: Triangle properties (angle sum 180°, side relationships) unlock many geometry problems.
Classifying triangles helps choose the right facts quickly.
Reasoning beats memorizing: justify every step.

atoms.title: Classify Triangles (by sides and angles)
atoms.core_idea: Triangles can be classified by side equality and angle type; classification reveals properties.
learning_objectives: Classify triangles as scalene/isosceles/equilateral and acute/right/obtuse.
Identify triangle type from a diagram or measurements.
State one property of isosceles/equilateral triangles.
common_misconceptions: Thinking an isosceles triangle must look 'symmetrical' in drawing.
Confusing right triangle with equilateral due to shape stereotypes.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Use markings to classify without measuring.
Identify triangles in real objects (signs, designs).

atoms.title: Angle Sum of a Triangle
atoms.core_idea: The interior angles of any triangle add to 180°.
learning_objectives: Find missing angle in a triangle using 180° sum.
Solve problems involving two or more triangles.
Explain reasoning using angle sum.
common_misconceptions: Using 360° instead of 180°.
Assuming triangle type changes the sum.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Design a triangle with one angle fixed.

atoms.title: Exterior Angle of a Triangle (intro)
atoms.core_idea: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles (and forms a linear pair with its adjacent interior angle).
learning_objectives: Identify an exterior angle in a triangle.
Use linear pair (180°) to compute exterior/interior.
Use exterior angle property in simple problems.
common_misconceptions: Adding the adjacent interior angle instead of the remote ones.
Confusing which angles are 'remote'.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Compute exterior angle using 180° then compare.
Find an angle in a polygon corner using triangle split.

atoms.title: Isosceles Triangle Base Angles
atoms.core_idea: In an isosceles triangle, angles opposite equal sides are equal.
learning_objectives: Use equal sides to infer equal base angles.
Solve missing angle problems in isosceles triangles.
Explain 'opposite equal sides' clearly.
common_misconceptions: Assuming equal angles imply isosceles without checking sides (or vice versa).
Mixing up which angles correspond.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Tap equal sides then compute angles.
Symmetry reasoning: fold line through apex.

atoms.title: Triangle Inequality (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Three lengths form a triangle only if the sum of any two sides is greater than the third.
learning_objectives: Determine if three lengths can form a triangle.
Explain using 'two sides must reach'.
Generate a valid third side range given two sides.
common_misconceptions: Using ≥ instead of >.
Checking only one pair of sides.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Sort sets of three lengths into possible/impossible.
Design a triangle for a craft project with stick lengths.

modules.title: Chapter 7: Congruence of Triangles
big_ideas: Congruence means 'same shape and size' (superimposable).
Triangle congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS) let you prove equality without measuring everything.
CPCTC connects congruence to solving for unknown sides/angles.

atoms.title: Congruent vs equal vs similar (superimposition idea)
atoms.core_idea: Congruent figures can be placed exactly on top of each other by rigid moves (slide/turn/flip).
learning_objectives: Identify congruent shapes in a set and justify why.
Distinguish 'equal length/angle' from 'congruent figure'.
Use rigid motions to explain congruence (no resizing).

misconceptions.symptom: Same shape but different size called congruent.

atoms.title: Triangle congruence: SSS and SAS
atoms.core_idea: Three sides determine a triangle; two sides and included angle also determine it uniquely.
learning_objectives: Apply SSS and SAS criteria to decide if triangles are congruent.
Identify 'included angle' correctly for SAS.
Use congruence criteria language in a proof outline.

misconceptions.symptom: Uses any angle, not the included angle.
misconceptions.fix: Show counterexample where two sides + non-included angle gives different triangles.

atoms.title: Triangle congruence: ASA and RHS
atoms.core_idea: Two angles + a side fix a triangle; for right triangles, hypotenuse + one side (RHS) is enough.
learning_objectives: Apply ASA and RHS criteria correctly.
Recognize right triangles and identify hypotenuse.
Explain why AAA does NOT prove congruence.

misconceptions.symptom: Thinks AAA gives congruence.
misconceptions.fix: Show two similar triangles with different sizes.

misconceptions.symptom: Mislabels hypotenuse.

atoms.title: CPCTC: Use congruence to find unknown parts
atoms.core_idea: Once triangles are congruent, corresponding sides/angles are equal (CPCTC).
learning_objectives: Match corresponding vertices correctly.
Compute missing sides/angles using CPCTC.
Avoid mixing up correspondence order.

misconceptions.symptom: Matches wrong vertices.
misconceptions.fix: Use consistent naming: list equal angles/sides in same order.

template_mix.notes: Apply in a simple word/diagram situation.

modules.title: Chapter 8: Comparing Quantities
big_ideas: Percent is 'out of 100' and connects fractions and decimals.
Ratios compare quantities multiplicatively; unit rate simplifies comparisons.
Successive percent changes are not additive; order matters.

atoms.title: Percent, Fraction, Decimal Conversions
atoms.core_idea: Percent, fractions, and decimals are three forms of the same value; choose the form that makes thinking easiest.
learning_objectives: Convert between percent, fraction, and decimal.
Use benchmarks (10%, 25%, 50%, 75%) for quick mental conversions.
Explain conversions using 'per 100'.
common_misconceptions: Treating percent sign as decoration (e.g., 0.25% = 0.25).
Confusing 25% with 0.25 (without converting).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Battery at 65%: fraction of charge left.

atoms.title: Find Percent of a Quantity
atoms.core_idea: A percent of a quantity is scaling: value × (percent/100).
learning_objectives: Compute p% of a number using multiplication.
Use benchmark decomposition (e.g., 35% = 10% + 10% + 10% + 5%).
Estimate to check reasonableness.
common_misconceptions: Multiplying by percent without converting (e.g., 60% of 50 = 3000).
Confusing 'of' with addition.

atoms.title: Increase/Decrease, Discount, Tax, Successive Changes
atoms.core_idea: Percent change scales the original: new = original × (1 ± p/100). Successive changes compound.
learning_objectives: Calculate final price after discount or increase.
Handle discount then tax (order matters).
Explain why 10% increase then 10% decrease is not 'back to original'.
common_misconceptions: Applying tax/discount on the wrong base amount.
Adding percents instead of multiplying successive changes.

atoms.title: Ratios and Rates (including unit rate)
atoms.core_idea: Ratios compare quantities multiplicatively; unit rate answers 'per 1'.
learning_objectives: Write ratios in multiple forms (a:b, a/b, 'a to b').
Compute unit rate and compare options.
Use ratios to scale recipes or maps.
common_misconceptions: Treating ratio as subtraction (difference) instead of multiplicative comparison.
Mixing units in rates (e.g., km with minutes without converting).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Find unit price to compare deals.
Sort ratio vs rate vs fraction examples.

atoms.title: Proportion (missing value) and Scaling
atoms.core_idea: Proportional relationships keep the same multiplicative factor; scaling multiplies both terms by the same factor.
learning_objectives: Solve missing-value proportion problems using scaling or cross-multiplication (later).
Decide if two ratios are equivalent.
Explain scaling factor in words.
common_misconceptions: Adding the same number instead of multiplying to scale.
Cross-multiplying blindly without understanding.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Use ratio table to find missing value.
Enlarging a picture on a grid.

atoms.title: Percent & Ratio Applications (choose the right model)
atoms.core_idea: Pick a model (percent multiplier, ratio table, unit rate) based on what the story is asking.
learning_objectives: Identify whether a situation is percent, ratio, or rate.
Solve mixed application problems using an appropriate representation.
Explain why your chosen model fits.
common_misconceptions: Using one method for every problem (hammer-nail syndrome).
Ignoring units (percent vs quantity).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Sort stories into percent vs ratio vs rate.
Create your own word problem for a given model.

modules.title: Chapter 9: Rational Numbers
big_ideas: Rational numbers include all numbers that can be written as p/q where q ≠ 0.
The number line organizes all rational numbers; between any two rationals there are infinitely many.
Properties (commutative, associative, distributive) help simplify and reason.

atoms.title: Rational Numbers on the Number Line
atoms.core_idea: Rational numbers include negative fractions and decimals; place them by magnitude, not by numerator/denominator separately.
learning_objectives: Represent rational numbers (fractions/decimals) on the number line.
Compare and order negative fractions and decimals.
Convert between forms when helpful.
common_misconceptions: Thinking -1/2 is less than -3/4 because 1/2 < 3/4 (ignoring negativity direction).
Confusing 'more negative' with 'greater'.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Debt ratios: owing 3/4 of a unit.

atoms.title: Add/Subtract Rational Numbers
atoms.core_idea: Rational addition/subtraction follows the same structure as integers; common denominators align parts.
learning_objectives: Add/subtract rational numbers including negatives.
Use common denominators and sign reasoning correctly.
Check answers by estimating magnitude.
common_misconceptions: Losing track of negative signs during conversion to common denominator.
Assuming subtraction always decreases.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Net gain/loss in fractions (e.g., of a tank).

atoms.title: Multiply/Divide Rational Numbers
atoms.core_idea: Multiplication scales; division asks 'how many of this quantity fit'. Signs follow integer rules.
learning_objectives: Multiply/divide rational numbers including negatives.
Simplify efficiently using cancellation.
Explain sign outcome using parity of negatives.
common_misconceptions: Flipping the wrong fraction in division.
Sign confusion when there are multiple negatives.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Multiply with cancellation; divide using reciprocal.
Scale a negative change (e.g., temperature drop doubled).

atoms.title: Properties of Operations (with examples & counterexamples)
atoms.core_idea: Properties (commutative/associative/distributive) are tools: use them when they simplify thinking.
learning_objectives: Identify commutative and associative properties for + and ×.
Use distributive property to simplify computations.
Recognize operations where a property does NOT apply (subtraction/division).
common_misconceptions: Assuming subtraction is commutative/associative.
Using distributive property incorrectly (e.g., (a+b)^2 = a^2+b^2).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Sort statements into true/false based on property.
Match property names to examples; fill steps.

atoms.title: Density of Rational Numbers (find a number between)
atoms.core_idea: Between any two different rational numbers, there exists another rational number (in fact, infinitely many).
learning_objectives: Find a rational number between two rational numbers (using average or common denominators).
Explain why there are infinitely many between.
Use this idea to refine estimates on a number line.
common_misconceptions: Thinking there is only one number between two given numbers.
Confusing 'next' number like with integers.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Use average to find a number between.
Find 3 different numbers between two given values.
Refine an estimate for √2 between 1.4 and 1.5 (optional enrichment).

modules.title: Chapter 10: Practical Geometry (Constructions)
big_ideas: Construction is not measurement: it uses rules (compass + straightedge) to create exact objects.
Parallel lines and triangle constructions rely on congruence ideas and angle properties.
Knowing the construction steps builds strong geometric thinking for higher grades.

atoms.title: Construction mindset: exactness, notation, and steps
atoms.core_idea: A construction is a sequence of justified steps; diagrams show intent, not artistic skill.
learning_objectives: Distinguish construction vs drawing vs measurement.
Read common construction marks (arcs, equal segments, equal angles).
Write/choose the correct ordered steps for a simple construction.

misconceptions.symptom: Uses ruler/protractor measurements as proof.
misconceptions.fix: Emphasize compass arcs and equal-radius reasoning.

template_mix.notes: Order steps for a basic segment/angle copy.

atoms.title: Construct a line parallel to a given line through a point
atoms.core_idea: Parallel construction uses equal corresponding/alternate angles built from arcs.
learning_objectives: Choose the correct method (copy an angle / use transversal).
Identify which angles must be equal to ensure parallel lines.
Order and justify steps.

misconceptions.symptom: Relies on looking parallel.
misconceptions.fix: Use angle-copy reasoning and show checks.

atoms.title: Construct a triangle (SSS and SAS)
atoms.core_idea: Some sets of measurements determine a unique triangle; construction mirrors congruence logic.
learning_objectives: Order the steps for SSS and SAS triangle constructions.
Identify 'included angle' for SAS construction.
Explain when a triangle cannot be constructed.

misconceptions.symptom: Attempts SSS when sides cannot form a triangle.
misconceptions.fix: Check sum of two sides > third.

template_mix.notes: Fix a wrong order or impossible triangle.
Apply in context (design a triangular frame).

atoms.title: Construct a triangle (ASA and RHS)
atoms.core_idea: Angles plus a side fix a triangle; for right triangles, hypotenuse + one leg is enough.
learning_objectives: Order steps for ASA construction.
Construct a right triangle given hypotenuse and one leg (RHS).
Identify when data is insufficient/ambiguous.

misconceptions.symptom: Uses wrong side in ASA (not included).
misconceptions.fix: Clarify which side is given relative to angles.

template_mix.notes: Decide if information determines a unique triangle.

modules.title: Chapter 11: Perimeter and Area
big_ideas: Perimeter measures boundary length; area measures covered surface.
Formulas come from decomposing shapes into known parts.
Units are part of the answer; converting units is scaling.

atoms.title: Perimeter of Polygons
atoms.core_idea: Perimeter is the total distance around a shape; add side lengths carefully with units.
learning_objectives: Compute perimeter of rectangles and general polygons.
Find unknown side lengths when perimeter is given.
Explain the difference between perimeter and area.
common_misconceptions: Confusing perimeter with area formulas.
Forgetting units or mixing units.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Perimeter of an L-shape by adding sides.
Fencing a garden with a missing side.

atoms.title: Area of Rectangle and Square (meaning + formula)
atoms.core_idea: Area counts unit squares; rectangle area = length × breadth.
learning_objectives: Explain area as counting unit squares.
Compute area of rectangles/squares.
Solve for missing dimension given area.
common_misconceptions: Using perimeter formula instead of area.
Mixing units (cm vs cm²).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Fill formula steps; solve missing dimension.
Student answers in cm not cm².
Tile a floor; compute tiles needed.

atoms.title: Area of Triangle and Parallelogram (decompose)
atoms.core_idea: Triangle area is half a rectangle/parallelogram with same base and height; parallelogram area = base × height.
learning_objectives: Compute area of a parallelogram using base and height.
Compute area of a triangle using 1/2 × base × height.
Identify base and height (perpendicular) correctly.
common_misconceptions: Using slanted side as height.
Forgetting the 1/2 factor for triangles.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Find area of a triangular sign board.

atoms.title: Composite Figures (add/subtract areas)
atoms.core_idea: Break complex shapes into rectangles/triangles; add or subtract areas carefully.
learning_objectives: Decompose composite shapes into known parts.
Compute area of composite figures.
Explain your decomposition strategy.
common_misconceptions: Double-counting overlapping parts.
Missing a part or using wrong dimensions.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Structured: draw parts → compute each → sum.
Painting a wall with a window cutout.

atoms.title: Unit Conversions (length and area)
atoms.core_idea: Converting units is scaling; area conversions scale by the square of the length factor.
learning_objectives: Convert between mm, cm, m, km (length).
Convert between cm² and m² (area) with correct scaling.
Detect unreasonable conversions with estimation.
common_misconceptions: Converting area using the same factor as length.
Moving decimal randomly without factor reasoning.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Floor area in m² from cm measurements.

modules.title: Chapter 12: Algebraic Expressions
big_ideas: Variables stand for numbers; algebra is generalized arithmetic.
Like terms can be combined because they represent the same 'unit'.
The distributive property links multiplication and addition, enabling expansion and factoring.

atoms.title: Variables & Translating Words to Expressions
atoms.core_idea: Translate situations into expressions by identifying the quantity and how it changes.
learning_objectives: Represent an unknown with a variable.
Translate verbal statements to algebraic expressions.
Distinguish expression vs equation.
common_misconceptions: Treating 'x' as a multiplication sign.
Writing expressions in the wrong order (e.g., '5 less than x' as 5 - x).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Translate '3 more than a number' and explain order.
Create an expression for a real scenario (tickets, points).

atoms.title: Terms, Coefficients, and Like Terms
atoms.core_idea: Like terms share the same variable part; you can combine only like with like.
learning_objectives: Identify terms, coefficients, and constants.
Combine like terms correctly.
Explain why 3x + 2x works but 3x + 2 does not combine.
common_misconceptions: Combining unlike terms (x + y = xy, or 3x + 2 = 5x).
Adding coefficients but changing variable part incorrectly.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Simplify perimeter expression of a rectangle with sides x+2.

atoms.title: Distributive Property (Expand and Factor basics)
atoms.core_idea: Distribute multiplication across addition: a(b+c)=ab+ac; factoring reverses it.
learning_objectives: Expand expressions like 3(x+4).
Factor simple expressions like 6x+12.
Explain distributive property using area/tiles.
common_misconceptions: Distributing incorrectly: 3(x+4)=3x+4.
Factoring by dividing only one term.

atoms.title: Evaluate Expressions (Substitution)
atoms.core_idea: To evaluate, substitute the given value for the variable and follow order of operations.
learning_objectives: Substitute values into expressions correctly (with parentheses).
Evaluate using order of operations.
Check reasonableness.
common_misconceptions: Dropping parentheses: evaluating 3x+2 with x=-4 as 3×-4+2 (ok) but mishandling 3(x+2).
Mixing variable value into coefficient incorrectly.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Evaluate a perimeter formula with given side length.

atoms.title: Patterns → Expressions (Generalization)
atoms.core_idea: A pattern can be described by a rule; algebra expresses the rule for any step number n.
learning_objectives: Describe a pattern in words and as an expression in n.
Use a table to connect n to output.
Check the rule using multiple values.
common_misconceptions: Using recursive rule only (add 3 each time) when explicit rule is asked.
Confusing n with the output.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Match a pattern table to a rule.

modules.title: Chapter 13: Exponents and Powers
big_ideas: Exponents compress repeated multiplication into a powerful notation.
Exponent laws describe patterns; they are not arbitrary rules.
Powers of 10 connect to place value and estimation.

atoms.title: Meaning of Exponents (repeated multiplication)
atoms.core_idea: a^n means multiply a by itself n times; the exponent counts factors, not the value.
learning_objectives: Write repeated multiplication using exponent notation and expand powers.
Evaluate small powers accurately.
Distinguish base and exponent.
common_misconceptions: Interpreting a^n as a×n.
Thinking 3^2 = 6.

atoms.title: Powers of 10 and Place Value
atoms.core_idea: 10^n shifts place value; it explains how decimals move when multiplying/dividing by powers of 10.
learning_objectives: Evaluate powers of 10 and express numbers using them.
Multiply/divide by 10^n using place value reasoning.
Estimate large numbers using powers of 10.
common_misconceptions: Moving decimal the wrong direction.
Confusing 10^2 with 10×2.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Fill shifts and check with estimation.
Multiply/divide by 10^n; write in expanded form.

atoms.title: Exponent Laws (same base)
atoms.core_idea: Exponent laws follow from counting factors: multiplying adds exponents; dividing subtracts.
learning_objectives: Use product and quotient laws: a^m × a^n, a^m ÷ a^n (a≠0).
Use power of a power: (a^m)^n.
Explain laws using factor expansion for small cases.
common_misconceptions: Adding exponents when bases are different: 2^3×3^3 = 6^6 (wrong).
Multiplying exponents incorrectly: (a^m)^n = a^(m+n) (wrong).

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Simplify an expression in a geometry formula.

atoms.title: Zero Exponent and Exponent 1 (why it works)
atoms.core_idea: To keep the quotient law consistent, a^0 must equal 1 (for a≠0); a^1 equals a.
learning_objectives: State and use a^0 = 1 (a≠0) and a^1 = a.
Explain a^0 using patterns/quotient law.
Avoid the '0 means 0' misconception.
common_misconceptions: Believing a^0 = 0.
Applying a^0 = 1 even when a=0 without discussion.

modules.title: Chapter 14: Symmetry
big_ideas: Symmetry is an invariant: some things stay the same under a transformation.
Transformations (reflect, rotate, translate) build spatial reasoning and proof habits.
Counting symmetry builds classification skills for shapes.

atoms.title: Line Symmetry (identify and draw)
atoms.core_idea: A line of symmetry splits a figure into mirror halves.
learning_objectives: Identify lines of symmetry in common shapes.
Draw a line of symmetry when it exists.
Recognize when a shape has no line symmetry.
common_misconceptions: Assuming every shape has at least one line of symmetry.
Drawing a line that 'looks centered' but doesn't mirror.

atoms.title: Rotational Symmetry (order)
atoms.core_idea: A figure has rotational symmetry if it matches itself after a rotation; the order counts how many matches in a full turn.
learning_objectives: Identify if a shape has rotational symmetry.
Determine the order of rotational symmetry.
Connect order to rotation angle (360°/order).
common_misconceptions: Confusing line symmetry with rotational symmetry.
Thinking any rotation counts even if it doesn't match.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Order of rotational symmetry of a square.
Spokes on a wheel and repeated patterns.

atoms.title: Reflections on a Grid (coordinate-free)
atoms.core_idea: Reflection flips a figure across a mirror line; corresponding points are the same distance from the mirror.
learning_objectives: Reflect a point/shape across a given line on a grid.
Identify corresponding points and equal distances.
Spot reflection errors (wrong distance or wrong side).
common_misconceptions: Sliding instead of flipping.
Measuring distance incorrectly from the mirror line.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Reflect a point across a vertical line.
Debug a reflection with wrong distance.

atoms.title: Translations and Rotations (grid moves)
atoms.core_idea: Translation slides without turning; rotation turns around a center point.
learning_objectives: Translate shapes by a given vector (up/down/left/right).
Rotate shapes by 90° multiples on a grid (optional).
Describe transformations in words.
common_misconceptions: Rotating when translation is required (or vice versa).
Rotating about wrong center.

modules.title: Chapter 15: Visualising Solid Shapes
big_ideas: 3D solids can be understood through nets (unfolding) and views (projection).
Counting faces/edges/vertices builds structure awareness.
Volume measures how much space a solid occupies; for a cuboid, it's L×B×H.

atoms.title: Faces, Edges, Vertices (classify solids)
atoms.core_idea: A solid is described by faces (surfaces), edges (line segments), and vertices (corners).
learning_objectives: Identify and count faces, edges, vertices for common solids.
Match nets to solids (intro).
Use precise vocabulary.
common_misconceptions: Counting curved surfaces incorrectly (e.g., cylinder).
Mixing edges with vertices.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Sort solids by having curved surface or not.

atoms.title: Nets of Cubes and Cuboids
atoms.core_idea: A net is a 2D pattern that folds into a 3D solid; edges must match and faces must not overlap when folded.
learning_objectives: Identify valid nets of a cube/cuboid.
Predict which faces become adjacent when folded.
Spot invalid nets (overlap or mismatch).
common_misconceptions: Assuming any arrangement of 6 squares makes a cube net.
Not considering overlap on folding.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Reason about adjacency in a cube net.
Choose valid net; explain adjacency (two-tier optional).
Debug an invalid net that overlaps.
Packaging design: net for a small box.

atoms.title: Views of Solids (top/front/side)
atoms.core_idea: Different views show different faces; combining views reconstructs the solid.
learning_objectives: Match a solid to its top/front/side views.
Count cubes from views in simple cases.
Explain ambiguity when views are insufficient.
common_misconceptions: Assuming the front view shows depth.
Overcounting hidden cubes.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Match a cube stack to views.

atoms.title: Volume of Cuboid (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Volume counts unit cubes; for a cuboid, volume = length × breadth × height.
learning_objectives: Explain volume as counting unit cubes.
Compute volume of cuboids.
Solve for a missing dimension given volume.
common_misconceptions: Confusing volume with surface area.
Using square units instead of cubic units.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Build layers of cubes to see L×B×H.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Probability (intro)
big_ideas: Probability measures how likely an event is, from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
For equally likely outcomes: P(event)=favorable/total.
Experimental probability approaches theoretical probability with more trials.

atoms.title: Outcomes and Sample Space
atoms.core_idea: A sample space lists all possible outcomes; events are subsets of outcomes.
learning_objectives: List outcomes for simple experiments (coin, die, spinner).
Identify events as sets of outcomes.
Count outcomes accurately.
common_misconceptions: Missing outcomes (incomplete sample space).
Treating outcomes as ordered/unordered incorrectly.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: List outcomes for two coin tosses.

atoms.title: Probability as a Fraction (equally likely)
atoms.core_idea: Probability is the fraction of outcomes that satisfy the event, when outcomes are equally likely.
learning_objectives: Compute probability of simple events.
Express probability as fraction, decimal, or percent.
Interpret 0, 1, and 1/2 in context.
common_misconceptions: Using favorable + total instead of favorable/total.
Assuming non-equally likely outcomes are equally likely without checking.

atoms.title: Complementary Events
atoms.core_idea: P(not A) = 1 − P(A).
learning_objectives: Find probability of 'not event'.
Solve problems where complement is easier than direct counting.
Explain why probabilities add to 1.
common_misconceptions: Adding probabilities incorrectly.
Forgetting total probability equals 1.

recommended_activity_sequence.notes: Probability of not picking a red ball from a bag.

atoms.title: Experimental Probability (simulate and interpret)
atoms.core_idea: Experimental probability = successes/trials; more trials usually stabilizes the estimate.
learning_objectives: Run a simple simulation (coin/spinner) and compute experimental probability.
Compare experimental to theoretical probability.
Explain variation in small samples.
common_misconceptions: Expecting small samples to match theoretical exactly.
Believing a run of outcomes must 'balance out immediately' (gambler's fallacy).

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Number Theory Foundations
big_ideas: Divisibility, primes, and remainders create patterns you can reason about (not memorize).
Parity (odd/even) and modular thinking are powerful 'shortcut' tools.
Many Olympiad problems become easy when you look for invariants and constraints.

atoms.title: Divisibility tests and smart factor spotting
atoms.core_idea: Divisibility rules are pattern tools; factor spotting makes calculations lighter.
learning_objectives: Use divisibility tests for 2,3,4,5,8,9,11 in reasoning.
Find HCF/LCM via prime factorisation and via reasoning shortcuts.
Explain why a divisibility test works for at least one rule (e.g., 3 or 9).

misconceptions.symptom: Applies rule but cannot detect when it fails.

atoms.title: Parity (odd/even) and quick contradiction checks
atoms.core_idea: Odd/even reasoning rules out impossible cases fast.
learning_objectives: Predict parity of sums/products without calculating fully.
Use parity to prove something cannot happen.
Spot hidden assumptions in 'always/never' claims.

misconceptions.symptom: Mixes rules for sum vs product.

atoms.title: Remainders and modular patterns (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Remainders repeat in cycles; spotting cycles prevents long computation.
learning_objectives: Find remainders of large powers using cycles (mod 2,3,4,5,8,9,10).
Explain the idea of 'mod' as remainder class.
Solve simple remainder puzzles.

misconceptions.symptom: Tries to compute huge powers directly.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Counting & Combinatorics (intro)
big_ideas: Count systematically: cases, tables, and 'fix one thing, vary the rest'.
Avoid double counting by being explicit about order and uniqueness.
Many problems are easiest when you draw a small complete list and then generalise.

atoms.title: Systematic listing and casework
atoms.core_idea: A clean list beats clever guessing.
learning_objectives: Create a case table for a counting problem.
Explain why your list is complete and non-overlapping.
Use symmetry to reduce cases when appropriate.

misconceptions.symptom: List stops early or overlaps.
misconceptions.fix: Use structure: fix a variable, vary the other.

atoms.title: Basic permutations vs combinations (sense-making, not formulas)
atoms.core_idea: Order matters sometimes; the story decides.
learning_objectives: Decide if order matters in a situation.
Solve small problems by reasoning and listing, then generalise patterns.
Avoid applying formulas blindly.

misconceptions.symptom: Treats selection and arrangement the same.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Geometry Challenges (angle chase & area reasoning)
big_ideas: Angle chasing is logic: use parallel lines, triangles, and straight lines strategically.
Area problems often simplify using cutting/rearranging and equal-height arguments.
A clean diagram and labeled information is half the solution.

atoms.title: Angle chase toolkit (repeatable moves)
atoms.core_idea: A small set of facts solves many Olympiad angle problems.
learning_objectives: Use parallel-line angle relationships confidently.
Use triangle angle-sum and exterior angles.
Spot isosceles/equilateral cues and use them.

misconceptions.symptom: Guesses without a chain of reasons.

template_mix.notes: Fill missing angle step and reason.

atoms.title: Area reasoning (equal base/height, cut & rearrange)
atoms.core_idea: Areas compare easily when heights or bases match; rearranging shapes reveals equality.
learning_objectives: Compare areas without calculating full units.
Use equal height arguments for triangles/parallelograms.
Solve puzzle-like area problems with rearrangement.

misconceptions.symptom: Thinks must compute exact area each time.

template_mix.notes: Match equal-area shapes; fill missing reasoning.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Algebra & Patterns (non-routine)
big_ideas: Patterns become solvable when you translate them into tables, expressions, or invariants.
Algebra is a language for structure, not just 'x'.
Many Olympiad problems are about choosing a smart representation.

atoms.title: Build and test rules for sequences (table → expression)
atoms.core_idea: Use input-output thinking to describe patterns.
learning_objectives: Generate the next terms from a rule and justify it.
Create a rule from a table (simple linear patterns).
Check a rule with multiple values.

misconceptions.symptom: Forms rule from one example only.

template_mix.notes: Fill missing step building a rule.

atoms.title: Inequality sense (bounds, not exact answers)
atoms.core_idea: Sometimes you only need a range; bounds are powerful.
learning_objectives: Use estimate bounds for sums/products.
Reason about min/max under simple constraints.
Explain why a value is impossible.

misconceptions.symptom: Searches for exact when bounds suffice.

modules.title: Engineering Foundation: Coordinate Thinking (early)
big_ideas: Coordinates are addresses; graphs are stories of relationships.
Many engineering entrance topics later rely on comfort with the coordinate plane.
You can start with simple plotting and patterns without formal 'functions'.

alignment.goal: Long-run bridge toward coordinate geometry used in higher classes / EAPCET

atoms.title: Plot and read points in the coordinate plane (Quadrant I first)
atoms.core_idea: A point (x,y) means 'x along, y up'.
learning_objectives: Plot points with positive coordinates accurately.
Read coordinates from a grid.
Connect coordinate changes to movement.

misconceptions.symptom: Swaps x and y.

atoms.title: See linear patterns on a table and on a graph
atoms.core_idea: Tables and graphs show the same relationship in different clothes.
learning_objectives: From a table, spot constant add pattern.
Plot the table as points and describe the trend.
Predict the next value and justify.

misconceptions.symptom: Describes appearance without relationship.
misconceptions.fix: Ask 'what changes when x increases by 1?'

template_mix.notes: Match table to graph; fill missing step.

modules.title: Engineering Foundation: Calculation Fluency (smart, not speed)
big_ideas: Entrance exams reward accuracy and efficiency; efficiency comes from strategies, not rushing.
Mental math shortcuts reduce cognitive load so you can think.
Estimation prevents silly mistakes.

alignment.goal: Build fluency that supports later competitive prep without increasing anxiety.

atoms.title: Estimation and sanity-checks (units, order of magnitude)
atoms.core_idea: A quick estimate catches many wrong answers.
learning_objectives: Estimate products/quotients using rounding.
Check if an answer is reasonable using units and magnitude.
Use reverse operation to check equations.

misconceptions.symptom: Treats estimation as random guessing.

atoms.title: Strategy toolkit: distributive, factoring, fraction sense
atoms.core_idea: Algebraic thinking starts as arithmetic strategy.
learning_objectives: Use distributive property for mental multiplication (e.g., 17×6 = (10+7)×6).
Simplify fraction calculations before multiplying/dividing.
Explain your shortcut.

misconceptions.symptom: Cancels across addition.
misconceptions.fix: Show only cancel factors in products.

template_mix.notes: Apply shortcut in a word context.

gamification_guardrails.rule: Games decorate learning, not replace it.
do: Tie rewards to evidence of learning (retrieval accuracy, transfer, persistence).
Use playful contexts inside math tasks, not as separate mini-games.
Unlock cosmetics via consistent practice and reflection, not by random taps.
dont: Let learners progress without mastering prerequisites.
Overuse MCQ when guessing is likely.
fun_without_fluff: Micro-stories and characters that frame problems (but keep math real).
Choice of representation (number line vs table) gives agency.
Streaks for 'checked my work' and 'fixed my mistake' moments.

context_guidelines: Use Indian contexts (rupees, cricket, school, local travel distances) sparingly and only when it clarifies the math.
Prefer metric units; show unit conversion explicitly when introduced.
Avoid culturally loaded stereotypes; keep names and contexts diverse.

notes: Some CBSE/NCERT editions have rationalised content. This curriculum keeps Congruence and Practical Geometry because they are foundational for later geometry and competitive exams; you can toggle them via 'scope_variants'.

scope_variants.description: All NCERT Class 7 chapters including Congruence and Practical Geometry.
A lighter variant where some schools may reduce/remove Congruence/Practical Geometry. Keep them as enrichment when needed.

tracks.title: CBSE / NCERT Class 7 Core (Full)
tracks.pacing_notes: Default. Aim for mastery per atom with spaced review; 4–5 sessions/week is plenty.

tracks.title: CBSE Core (Rationalised schools) + keep key geometry as enrichment
tracks.pacing_notes: If school omits chapters, keep short weekly enrichment so geometry foundations stay strong.

weekly_structure.notes: Non-routine problems; focus on reasoning and explanations.

overlay_plan.guardrail: Do NOT add speed pressure; prioritize reasoning chains and clarity.

tracks.title: Engineering Foundation (long runway to AP EAPCET) while in Class 7

overlay_plan.guardrail: Fluency = smart strategies + accuracy; avoid timed drills until confidence is stable.

exam_alignment.olympiad_note: Many school olympiads at Class 7 include both syllabus math and reasoning/pattern problems; enrichment modules target that style.
exam_alignment.eapcet_note: AP EAPCET (engineering) later emphasizes algebra, coordinate geometry, trigonometry, vectors, probability/statistics, calculus at intermediate level; this curriculum builds pre-requisites early via reasoning, fluency and coordinate comfort.
